title: -og/-eg/-ög verbs
sentences: Everyone is shivering in the cold at the bus stop.
The candle flame is flickering/flaring quietly in the draft.
He was humming quietly to himself on the way to work.
The leaves fell from the tree spinning.
The baby was puffing while trying to talk.
His gait is staggering/swaying from fatigue.
Someone was muttering quietly in the dark.
The little boy was sobbing bitterly in the corner.
The dog is happily wagging its tail while whimpering.
His hand is trembling from the tension.
The light down feather is floating in the air.
The patient is sweating from fever and tossing/turning in bed.
The logs are burning crackling in the fire.
The crowd is surging/streaming through the streets.
His clothes are dripping with water.
The children are laughing out loud happily on the playground.
The car wheel is spinning on the ice.
The window is banging in the wind and rattling.
In the heat, the dogs lie panting in the shade.
In the dark, something is dragging itself and creaking.
The little brook is splashing/babbling across the stones.
The tired wanderer is trudging/shuffling along the road.
The fridge is buzzing quietly in the kitchen.
The examinee is nervously drumming/thumping with his foot.
The birds are chirping and hopping around happily.
The rain is tapping on the roof.
The wind is roaring/humming in the pine forest.
The sea is murmuring/rumbling in the distance.
The heavy machine is thundering/rumbling in the factory.
The wall clock is ticking in the quiet room.
The typewriter is clicking/clattering on the table.
The old gate screeches/grates if it is opened.
The teapot whistles/shrieks if the water is boiling.
The wounded soldier is whimpering/moaning quietly.
The audience is murmuring/muttering during the break.
The hot oil is sizzling in the pan.
The frogs are croaking in the reeds.
The engine is puffing/chugging on the cold morning.
The dry branches are crunching under our feet.
The toddler is stomping/tapping his feet from impatience.
dictionary:
didereg - to shiver
lobog - to flicker / flare
dúdol - to hum
pörög - to spin
pöfög - to puff / chug
imbolyog - to stagger / sway
motyog - to mutter
zokog - to sob
nyüszög - to whimper
remeg - to tremble
lebeg - to float
forog - to spin / turn
pattog - to crackle / pop
hömpölyög - to surge / stream
csöpög - to drip
kacag - to laugh out loud
zörög - to rattle
liheg - to pant
nyikorog - to creak
csobog - to splash / babble
vánszorog - to trudge / shuffle
zümmög - to buzz
dobog - to thump / drum
csiripel - to chirp
kopog - to tap / knock
zúg - to roar / hum
morajlik - to murmur / rumble
dübörög - to thunder / rumble
ketyeg - to tick
kattog - to click / clatter
csikorog - to screech / grate
sipol - to whistle / shriek
nyöszörög - to whimper / moan
mormog - to murmur
serceg - to sizzle
kuruttyol - to croak
ropog - to crunch / crackle
topog - to stomp / tap feet
